### INPUTS
[Information 1]: ```
[Tutorial start]On crisp fall mornings, warm your belly with a breakfast that celebrates one of the most popular flavors of fall: pumpkin spice latte muffins. It takes about 30 minutes to make streusel-topped pumpkin spice latte muffins from start to finish. Things you'll need are listed next. 1/2 cup rolled oats (not instant). 
*1/2 cup flour.*
1/2 cup packed brown sugar. 1/2 cup roasted pumpkin seeds. 1/4 cup softened butter. 2 2/3 cups all-purpose flour. 3 tablespoons espresso powder. ```

[Information 2]: ```
[Tutorial start]On crisp fall mornings, warm your belly with a breakfast that celebrates one of the most popular flavors of fall: pumpkin spice latte muffins. It takes about 30 minutes to make streusel-topped pumpkin spice latte muffins from start to finish. Things you'll need are listed next. 
*1/2 cup rolled oats (not instant).*
1/2 cup flour. 1/2 cup packed brown sugar. 1/2 cup roasted pumpkin seeds. 1/4 cup softened butter. 2 2/3 cups all-purpose flour. ```

You are given two excerpts from tutorial videos about Making Muffins. Each excerpt incldues a highlighted piece of information. Identify at least one aspect of the task context (a particular temporal segmentation) that would assign DIFFERENT segment labels to the highlighted pieces of information.

### INPUTS
[Information 1]: ```
Butter and flour half of the muffin tins as a release method. Coat butter across the muffin cavity, add a good dash of flour, move the flour around, and dump out the excess flour. Use paper muffin liners for the rest of the tin cavities to produce taller muffins but with less crisp edge. Paper liners go a bit higher and prevent the mushroom-shaped muffin top while still allowing a nice dome. Transfer batter into the muffin tin. 
*If you prefer a nice crispy muffin edge, bake without paper liners.*
When baking without paper liners, be careful to add enough butter and flour so muffins pop out easily. Use a large ice cream scooper to transfer batter into the muffin tin. Fill the muffin cavities all the way to the top for big bakery-style muffins. Normally cupcake batter fills two-thirds of the way, but for these muffins the cups should be filled full. When filling paper liners, avoid getting batter on the edges to prevent burning. ```

[Information 2]: ```
Coat butter across the muffin cavity, add a good dash of flour, move the flour around, and dump out the excess flour. Use paper muffin liners for the rest of the tin cavities to produce taller muffins but with less crisp edge. Paper liners go a bit higher and prevent the mushroom-shaped muffin top while still allowing a nice dome. Transfer batter into the muffin tin. If you prefer a nice crispy muffin edge, bake without paper liners. 
*When baking without paper liners, be careful to add enough butter and flour so muffins pop out easily.*
Use a large ice cream scooper to transfer batter into the muffin tin. Fill the muffin cavities all the way to the top for big bakery-style muffins. Normally cupcake batter fills two-thirds of the way, but for these muffins the cups should be filled full. When filling paper liners, avoid getting batter on the edges to prevent burning. Batter on the edges will burn and mainly affects appearance rather than bake quality. ```

Greener bananas have a better flavor. Decide how many bananas to buy based on how many will be eaten in the next few days. Consider whether one banana per day per person is appropriate when deciding how many to buy. Consider whether bananas will be used in cereal or other dishes when deciding how many to buy. The ripeness (how green the bananas are) is the most important factor in deciding whether to buy them. ```

[Information 2]: ```
[Tutorial start]Going to the grocery store has become a difficult quest to find the perfect bananas. The Clothier household prefers bananas that are still a bit green. Greener bananas are firmer. 
*Greener bananas have a better flavor.*
Decide how many bananas to buy based on how many will be eaten in the next few days. Consider whether one banana per day per person is appropriate when deciding how many to buy. Consider whether bananas will be used in cereal or other dishes when deciding how many to buy. The ripeness (how green the bananas are) is the most important factor in deciding whether to buy them. Sometimes buy some bananas that will be perfect in a couple of days and some that are perfect right now. ```

### INPUTS
- Aspects of a task context, each labeled with an ID in square brackets (e.g., "[F1] ..."):  
[F1] (what) Ingredient type (Plural: Ingredient types) -- Divide the ingredients list into categories by the kind of ingredient (e.g., flours, grains/oats, sugars, fats, seeds, flavorings). Each listed item is assigned to the category that best matches the noun in the phrase.
Guidelines for defining labels: ```
- Read each ingredient line and identify the head noun(s) (e.g., 'flour', 'rolled oats', 'brown sugar', 'butter', 'pumpkin seeds').
- Map the head noun to a broader ingredient category: 'flour' -> Flour/Flour mix; 'oats' -> Oats/Grain; 'brown sugar' -> Sugar; 'butter' -> Fat; 'pumpkin seeds' -> Seeds/Nuts.
- If a phrase contains modifiers (e.g., 'not instant', 'packed', 'softened'), ignore modifiers for category assignment but preserve them for detail.
- Assign a single category label per ingredient line. When an ingredient could belong to multiple categories, prefer the most specific category matching the head noun.
```
Example labels: ```
[S1] Flour
Definition: '1/2 cup flour' — a ground-wheat baking flour ingredient; categorized under flours/baking dry base.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
No examples contents and context are available.
```
[S2] Rolled oats
Definition: '1/2 cup rolled oats (not instant)' — a whole-grain oat ingredient; categorized under oats/grains.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
No examples contents and context are available.
```
```
[F2] (when) Stage (Plural: Stages) -- Divide the recipe transcript into temporal stages such as Preparation/Setup (decisions to make before or at the start), Transfer/Filling (actions of putting batter into tins), and Baking/Execution (steps and precautions taken while baking). Each highlighted sentence should be labeled according to which stage it belongs to: whether it is advising a preparation choice or an execution-time precaution.
Guidelines for defining labels: ```
- Label a sentence as 'Preparation' if it gives a choice, preference, or setup instruction that should be decided or done before filling or baking (words like 'if you prefer', 'use', 'choose', or describing outcome trade-offs).
- Label a sentence as 'Execution' if it warns or instructs about what to do during the action of baking or immediately before placing tins in the oven (phrases like 'when baking', 'be careful', or step-specific cautions).
- Use adjacent context to determine timing: sentences immediately preceding 'transfer batter' or 'fill the muffin cavities' are likely Preparation; sentences referencing 'when baking' or the act of removing from oven are Execution.
```
Example labels: ```
[S1] Preparation
Definition: Guidance or choice to make before or at setup (e.g., whether to use paper liners to alter final texture).
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
No examples contents and context are available.
```
[S2] Execution
Definition: Precautions or step-specific instructions to follow during the baking/firing stage or while performing the action (e.g., how to ensure muffins pop out when baking without liners).
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
No examples contents and context are available.
```
```
[F3] (why) Outcome (Plural: Outcomes) -- Partition guidance by the purpose or subgoal it serves: Aesthetic/Texture outcomes (instructions that explain how to achieve a particular look or texture), Release/Removal outcomes (instructions meant to ensure easy removal or avoid sticking), and Safety/Quality outcomes (prevent burning, improve bake quality). Each highlighted sentence is labeled according to the primary outcome it addresses.
Guidelines for defining labels: ```
- If the sentence describes how something will look or feel (crisp edge, taller muffins, dome), label it as 'Aesthetic/Texture'.
- If the sentence describes ensuring the muffin can be removed easily or preventing sticking, label it as 'Release/Removal'.
- If the sentence focuses on preventing burning or affecting bake quality, label it as 'Safety/Quality'.
- When a sentence mentions both appearance and a functional effect, choose the label corresponding to the main verb or the explicit goal described.
```
Example labels: ```
[S1] Aesthetic
Definition: Instructions whose primary goal is to change appearance or texture (e.g., baking without liners for a crispy edge).
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
No examples contents and context are available.
```
[S2] Release
Definition: Instructions aimed at ensuring easy removal from pan or preventing sticking (e.g., add enough butter/flour when baking without liners).
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
No examples contents and context are available.
```
```
[F4] (what) Focus Object (Plural: Focus Objects) -- Divide the recipe content by the main physical/object focus being described: ingredients or components that go inside the muffins (fillings) versus components that go on top or outside (toppings/streusel) versus general product descriptors.
Guidelines for defining labels: ```
- Look for nouns that name ingredients or components (e.g., 'blueberries', 'streusel', 'batter').
- If the sentence describes something that will be mixed into the batter, label as 'Filling' or 'Interior'.
- If the sentence describes something that will be applied on top or as a finish, label as 'Topping' or 'Exterior'.
- If the sentence describes the overall muffin (texture, moistness), label as 'Product description'.
```
Example labels: ```
[S1] Filling
Definition: An ingredient intended to be mixed into the muffin batter (e.g., blueberries).
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
No examples contents and context are available.
```
[S2] Topping
Definition: A component applied on top or as a finish to the muffin (e.g., brown sugar streusel).
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
No examples contents and context are available.
```
```
[F5] (why) Purpose (Plural: Purposes) -- Segment content by the intended role or goal of the mentioned element in the recipe: core/flavoring ingredient, finishing/texture enhancer, or general product claims.
Guidelines for defining labels: ```
- If the sentence emphasizes the main ingredient that defines the recipe (e.g., 'loaded with blueberries'), label as 'Core ingredient'.
- If the sentence emphasizes a finishing element that modifies appearance or texture (e.g., 'topped with streusel'), label as 'Finish/topping'.
- If the sentence describes overall qualities (fluffy, moist), label as 'Product claim/description'.
```
Example labels: ```
[S1] Core ingredient
Definition: Describes an ingredient that defines the recipe's main flavor or identity (blueberries).
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
No examples contents and context are available.
```
[S2] Finish/topping
Definition: Describes an element added as a topping or finishing touch to affect texture/appearance (brown sugar streusel).
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
No examples contents and context are available.
```
```
[F6] (what) Property type (Plural: Property types) -- Split statements that describe banana characteristics into categories by the kind of attribute they claim (e.g., texture, flavor, ripeness/visual). Each statement in the transcript that asserts a property should be labeled according to which attribute it describes.
Guidelines for defining labels: ```
- Look for short declarative claims about bananas ("X are Y").
- Assign 'Texture' when the claim concerns firmness, softness, or mouthfeel (words like firm, soft, chewy).
- Assign 'Flavor' when the claim concerns taste, sweetness, or flavor quality (words like flavor, taste, sweet, bitter).
- Assign 'Ripeness' when the claim describes color/state related to maturation (green, ripe, overripe).
- If a claim mentions multiple attributes, choose the primary attribute emphasized in the sentence.
```
Example labels: ```
[S1] Texture
Definition: Claims about firmness or physical feel of the banana (e.g., 'firmer').
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
No examples contents and context are available.
```
[S2] Flavor
Definition: Claims about taste or flavor quality of the banana (e.g., 'better flavor').
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
No examples contents and context are available.
```
[S3] Ripeness
Definition: Statements explicitly about how green/ripe the banana is or about ripening state.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
No examples contents and context are available.
```
```
[F7] (why) Informational role (Plural: Informational roles) -- Label each highlighted statement according to whether it functions primarily as an explanation of a preference/observation (justification) or as an explicit factor to use when deciding what to buy (decision criterion/tip).
Guidelines for defining labels: ```
- If the sentence explains why the household prefers a certain banana (gives reason/observation), label as 'Justification'.
- If the sentence is presented as a factor to consider when choosing how many or which bananas to buy, label as 'Decision factor'.
- Look at surrounding sentences: if the claim is immediately linked to 'decide' or 'consider when deciding', prefer 'Decision factor'.
- When a claim both explains and informs buying, choose the role most central to the sentence's placement and wording.
```
Example labels: ```
[S1] Justification
Definition: An explanatory statement giving a reason for a household preference or observation.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
No examples contents and context are available.
```
[S2] Decision factor
Definition: A statement framed as a consideration or criterion to use when deciding what to buy.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
No examples contents and context are available.
```
```

### GOAL
Combine the given aspects of a task context to get a set of aspects of a task context that:
- Are orthogonal (the segmentation wrt one aspect does not deterministically fix the segmentation wrt another aspect).
- Are single-slot (the segmentation title and labels are one short phrase <3 words).
- Cover all initial aspects of a task context.

### POSSIBLE TYPES OF ASPECTS:
| Type | Example Titles | Example Labels | Example Distinction |
|------|----------------|----------------|----------------------|
| When | Stage of process | Setup / Execution | Different steps in time |
| Why | Purpose / Subgoal | Collect Data / Analyze Data | Different goals or intentions |
| Where | Environment | Field / Lab | Different physical or digital settings |
| What | Object of focus | Hardware / Software | Working on different components |
| How | Method / Tool used | Manual / Automated | Using different approaches or tools |

### PROCEDURE
Iterate until stable:
1) Check for orthogonality:
    - Redefine or replace non-orthogonal pairs with independent aspects of a task context.  
    - Example (WRONG: not independent):  
        - [F3] Physical settings
        - [F4] Settings
        - Settings are more general than physical settings, so can focus on one of the two.
    - Example (CORRECT: independent redesign):  
        - [F4] Settings
2) Check for single-slot:
    - Rephrase aspects of a task context so that segmentation title and labels fit in less than 3 words.
    - Example (WRONG: too long):  
        - [F5] Task phase segmentation
    - Example (CORRECT: single-slot):  
        - [F5] Phases
4) Check for coverage:
    - Ensure the new set preserves all the meaning of the original aspects of a task context.

### EXIT CONDITION
The final aspect set is smallest, orthogonal, single-slot, and fully covers the initial set.

- Tutorial-style transcript with timestamps (in seconds):
[0 - 1] The perfect combination of spicy pumpkin and dreamy cheesecake married together in a bite-sized muffin.  It's the treat you've been waiting for!
[2 - 3] These soft muffins with a saucy swirl of cheesecake make for the perfect treat to bring to all of your holiday gatherings.  Whether your into jumbo muffins, or bite-sized minis, these muffins are sure to be an instant hit !
[4 - 5] Step 1: Ingredients
[5 - 6] TOOLS:
[6 - 7] Mini Muffin Tin
[7 - 8] Mixer
[8 - 9] Digital Scale - I like this one
[10 - 11] MUFFINS:
[11 - 12] 1 15 oz can pumpkin
[12 - 13] 1/4 cup vegetable oil
[13 - 14] 2 large eggs
[14 - 15] 1 (200g) cup sugar
[15 - 16] 1 teaspoon vanilla
[16 - 17] 1 1/2 cups (188g) all-purpose flour
[17 - 18] 1 teaspoon baking powder
[18 - 19] 1/2 teaspoon baking soda
[19 - 20] 1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon
[20 - 21] 1/2 teaspoon ground ginger
[21 - 22] 1/2 teaspoon ground nutmeg
[22 - 23] 1/8 teaspoon ground cloves
[23 - 24] 1/2 teaspoon salt
[24 - 25] 1/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper
[25 - 26] FILLING:
[26 - 27] 8 ounces (200g) cream cheese, at room temperature
[27 - 28] 1 large egg yolk
[28 - 29] 5 tablespoons (75g) sugar
[29 - 30] 1/8 teaspoon vanilla extract
[30 - 31] Chopped nuts (walnuts, pecans) (optional)
[32 - 33] Step 2: Muffins
[33 - 34] Preheat oven to 350F (180C)
[35 - 36] Mix canned pumpkin, oil, and sugar together, either by hand or with a mixer on low.
[36 - 37] Add in eggs, one at a time, combining thoroughly after each.
[37 - 38] Add vanilla.
[39 - 40] Whisk together flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, and spices.
[41 - 42] Slowly add flour mixture to liquids, combining thoroughly and scraping the sides of the bowl with a spatula until well combined.
[43 - 44] Step 3: Filling
[44 - 45] Mix together cream cheese, sugar, egg yolk and vanilla until well combined.
[46 - 47] Step 4: Assemble
[47 - 48] Grease your muffin tins or line with paper cups.
[49 - 50] Drop in spoonfuls of pumpkin mixture.
[50 - 51] Add smaller spoonfuls of cream cheese mixture on top.
[51 - 52] Swirl with a skewer.
[53 - 54] Optional:  top with crushed nuts.  Pumpkin seeds (pepitas) are also a great topping!
[55 - 56] Step 5: Bake
[56 - 57] Bake as follows, turning the tins half way through baking times:
[58 - 59] mini muffins: 20-25 min
[59 - 60] standard muffins: 25-30 min
[60 - 61] jumbo muffins: 30-40 min
[63 - 64] Wasn't that easy?
[65 - 66] Enjoy!    

### GOAL
Return an updated list of segment labels for temporal segmentation of the tutorial based on Ingredient types (including existing and any new ones needed to cover the given transcript), each with 1-2 concrete examples grounded in the given transcript (or reused from the existing labels).

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- Read the ingredient line and identify the head noun (e.g., 'flour', 'oats', 'butter', 'pumpkin seeds').
- Map the head noun to a single broader category (Flour, Oats/Grain, Sugar, Fat, Seeds/Nuts, Liquid, Leavening, Spice/Flavoring, Dairy, Fruit).
- Ignore modifiers that affect form or preparation (e.g., 'softened', 'packed') when assigning the category.
- If ambiguous, pick the most specific category matching the head noun (e.g., 'brown sugar' → Sugar).

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### OUTPUT
Return a list of segment labels. Each segment label should have the following fields:
- id: id of the segment label
- label: short text less than 2-3 words
- definition: elaboration of what the segment label means
- examples: 1-2 short representative content and context that would be labeled as the segment label

NOTES
- Ground everything in the provided inputs; no external knowledge or speculation.
- Do not create duplicate or overlapping segment labels.
- Keep examples short and specific; avoid paraphrasing for the 'content' field.

ROLE: user

- Existing segment labels:
[S1] Flour
Definition: Ground-wheat or baking flours used as the dry base (e.g., 'all-purpose flour').
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: all-purpose flour
	- Context 1: Whisk together flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, and spices.  1 1/2 cups (188g) all-purpose flour
```
[S2] Sugar
Definition: Granulated, brown, or other sugars used as sweeteners.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: 1 (200g) cup sugar
	- Context 1: Add vanilla.  1 (200g) cup sugar  1 teaspoon vanilla
	- Content 2: 5 tablespoons (75g) sugar
	- Context 2: Mix together cream cheese, sugar, egg yolk and vanilla until well combined.  5 tablespoons (75g) sugar
```
[S3] Fat
Definition: Butter, oil, or other fats used in the batter or for greasing.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: 1/4 cup vegetable oil
	- Context 1: Mix canned pumpkin, oil, and sugar together, either by hand or with a mixer on low.  1/4 cup vegetable oil
```
[S4] Seeds/Nuts
Definition: Seeds or nuts used as mix-ins or toppings (e.g., 'pumpkin seeds').
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: Chopped nuts (walnuts, pecans) (optional)
	- Context 1: FILLING:  8 ounces (200g) cream cheese, at room temperature  Chopped nuts (walnuts, pecans) (optional)
	- Content 2: Pumpkin seeds (pepitas)
	- Context 2: Optional:  top with crushed nuts.  Pumpkin seeds (pepitas) are also a great topping!
```
[S5] Liquid
Definition: Water, milk, buttermilk, eggs, or other liquid ingredients.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: 1 15 oz can pumpkin
	- Context 1: Mix canned pumpkin, oil, and sugar together, either by hand or with a mixer on low.  1 15 oz can pumpkin
	- Content 2: 2 large eggs
	- Context 2: Mix canned pumpkin, oil, and sugar together, either by hand or with a mixer on low.  Add in eggs, one at a time, combining thoroughly after each.  2 large eggs
```
[S6] Leavening
Definition: Baking powder, baking soda, yeast or similar rising agents.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: 1 teaspoon baking powder
	- Context 1: Whisk together flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, and spices.  1 teaspoon baking powder
	- Content 2: 1/2 teaspoon baking soda
	- Context 2: Whisk together flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, and spices.  1/2 teaspoon baking soda
```
[S7] Dairy
Definition: Milk, yogurt, cream, or cheese distinct from fats (when listed separately).
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: 8 ounces (200g) cream cheese
	- Context 1: FILLING:  8 ounces (200g) cream cheese, at room temperature  Mix together cream cheese, sugar, egg yolk and vanilla until well combined.
	- Content 2: 1 large egg yolk
	- Context 2: FILLING:  8 ounces (200g) cream cheese, at room temperature  1 large egg yolk
```
[S8] Spice/Flavor
Definition: Spices and flavorings like cinnamon, vanilla, or cocoa.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: 1 teaspoon vanilla
	- Context 1: Add in eggs, one at a time, combining thoroughly after each.  Add vanilla.  1 teaspoon vanilla
	- Content 2: 1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon
	- Context 2: Whisk together flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, and spices.  1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon
```
[S9] Fruit
Definition: Fresh, canned or dried fruits intended as mix-ins or main flavor (e.g., 'pumpkin').
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: 1 15 oz can pumpkin
	- Context 1: The perfect combination of spicy pumpkin and dreamy cheesecake married together...  1 15 oz can pumpkin
```
- Tutorial-style transcript with timestamps (in seconds):
[0 - 1] On crisp fall mornings, warm your belly with a breakfast that celebrates one of the most popular flavors of fall: pumpkin spice latte muffins. It only takes about 30 minutes to make these streusel-topped muffins, from start to delicious finish.
[2 - 3] Things You'll Need
[3 - 4] 1/2 cup rolled oats (not instant)
[4 - 5] 1/2 cup flour
[5 - 6] 1/2 cup brown sugar, packed
[6 - 7] 1/2 cup roasted pumpkin seeds
[7 - 8] 1/4 cup butter, softened
[8 - 9] 2 2/3 cup all-purpose flour
[9 - 10] 3 Tbsp. espresso powder
[10 - 11] 2 tsp. baking soda
[11 - 12] 1 tsp. salt
[12 - 13] 1 can of pumpkin pie filling, 15 oz.
[13 - 14] 1/4 cup sugar
[14 - 15] 1 cup brown sugar, packed
[15 - 16] 1 cup vegetable oil
[16 - 17] 4 large eggs
[17 - 18] 1 cup white chocolate chips
[18 - 19] Cupcake liners
[19 - 20] Muffin pan
[21 - 22] 1. Make the streusel topping
[22 - 23] To begin, heat the oven to 350°F. Place paper liners in a muffin pan and set aside.
[24 - 25] In a small bowl, combine the rolled oats, 1/2 cup of flour, 1/2 cup of brown sugar, roasted pumpkin seeds, and softened butter. Combine thoroughly and set aside (to use as the streusel topping later).
[26 - 27] 2. Mix the flour base for the muffins
[27 - 28] Sift together 2 2/3 cups of flour, 3 tablespoons of espresso powder, 2 teaspoons of baking soda, and 1 teaspoon of salt.
[29 - 30] 3. Make the pumpkin mixture
[30 - 31] Combine the pumpkin pie filling, 1/4 cup of sugar, 1 cup of brown sugar, and 1 cup of vegetable oil. Lightly beat 4 large eggs. Add to the mixture and mix well.
[32 - 33] 4. Combine the wet ingredients with the flour base
[33 - 34] Make a small well in the dry ingredients, and then add the wet ingredients. Stir to moisten.
[35 - 36] 5. Add the chocolate chips
[36 - 37] Add 1 cup of white chocolate chips and stir until thoroughly combined.
[38 - 39] 6. Fill the liners and top with streusel
[39 - 40] Spoon the batter into the prepared muffin tin, filling each liner about 2/3 full. Top each muffin with the streusel.
[41 - 42] 7. Bake the muffins
[42 - 43] Bake for 18 to 20 minutes. Serve warm.    

### GOAL
Return an updated list of segment labels for temporal segmentation of the tutorial based on Ingredient types (including existing and any new ones needed to cover the given transcript), each with 1-2 concrete examples grounded in the given transcript (or reused from the existing labels).

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- Read the ingredient line and identify the head noun (e.g., 'flour', 'oats', 'butter', 'pumpkin seeds').
- Map the head noun to a single broader category (Flour, Oats/Grain, Sugar, Fat, Seeds/Nuts, Liquid, Leavening, Spice/Flavoring, Dairy, Fruit).
- Ignore modifiers that affect form or preparation (e.g., 'softened', 'packed') when assigning the category.
- If ambiguous, pick the most specific category matching the head noun (e.g., 'brown sugar' → Sugar).

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### OUTPUT
Return a list of segment labels. Each segment label should have the following fields:
- id: id of the segment label
- label: short text less than 2-3 words
- definition: elaboration of what the segment label means
- examples: 1-2 short representative content and context that would be labeled as the segment label

NOTES
- Ground everything in the provided inputs; no external knowledge or speculation.
- Do not create duplicate or overlapping segment labels.
- Keep examples short and specific; avoid paraphrasing for the 'content' field.

- Tutorial-style transcript with timestamps (in seconds):
[0 - 1] Classic blueberry muffins are nearly impossible to beat. Sweet, fluffy and studded with tangy blueberries, these muffins are always a favorite for breakfast, brunch or a snack. This easy blueberry muffin recipe is a keeper for anytime you're in need of a comforting treat. With plenty of room for adaptation, you can make these muffins gluten-free, refined sugar-free or dairy-free.
[2 - 3] Things You'll Need
[3 - 4] 3 cups all-purpose flour
[4 - 5] 1 cup light brown sugar, packed
[5 - 6] 1 tablespoon baking powder
[6 - 7] 1/2 teaspoon sea salt
[7 - 8] 2 eggs, lightly beaten
[8 - 9] 1 cup buttermilk
[9 - 10] 1/2 cup canola oil
[10 - 11] 1 2/3 cups fresh or frozen blueberries
[12 - 13] Preparation
[13 - 14] Heat the oven to 375 F. Coat a muffin tray with nonstick spray, or line your muffin tray with baking cups. Mix the flour, brown sugar, baking powder and salt to a mixing bowl. In a separate mixing bowl, combine the eggs, buttermilk and canola oil.
[14 - 15] {image caption}{Combine wet and dry ingredients in separate bowls}
[15 - 16] Stir together the dry ingredients until well combined. Similarly, whisk together the wet ingredients until combined.
[17 - 18] {image caption}{Stir together the ingredients}
[19 - 20] Pour the wet ingredients into the bowl with the dry ingredients, and stir until just combined.
[21 - 22] {image caption}{Combine wet and dry ingredients.}
[23 - 24] Add the blueberries, and gently fold them into the batter using a rubber spatula until just combined.
[25 - 26] {image caption}{Fold blueberries into muffin batter}
[27 - 28] Scoop blueberry muffin batter into the prepared muffin tray, filling the holes 3/4 of the way up.
[29 - 30] {image caption}{Scoop batter into muffin tray}
[31 - 32] Bake them on the center rack for 30 to 35 minutes or until the muffins test clean when poked in the center.
[33 - 34] {image caption}{Bake muffins in preheated oven.}
[35 - 36] Allow the muffins to cool at least 10 minutes before serving. Serve them warm with butter and honey.
[37 - 38] {image caption}{Allow muffins to cool before eating.}
[39 - 40] Tip
[40 - 41] To make these muffins gluten-free, you can replace the regular all-purpose flour with gluten-free all-purpose flour. For a dairy-free recipe, replace the buttermilk with unsweetened almond milk. If you are avoiding refined sugar, replace the brown sugar with coconut sugar. You also can use coconut oil or grapeseed oil instead of canola oil.
[42 - 43] Note that bake times may differ for those who live at high elevation.

### INPUTS
- Existing segment labels:
[S1] Flour
Definition: Ground-wheat or baking flours used as the dry base (e.g., 'all-purpose flour').
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: 3 cups all-purpose flour
	- Context 1: Things You'll Need 3 cups all-purpose flour
	- Content 2: 2 2/3 cup all-purpose flour
	- Context 2: Sift together 2 2/3 cups of flour, 3 tablespoons of espresso powder, 2 teaspoons of baking soda, and 1 teaspoon of salt.
```
[S2] Sugar
Definition: Granulated, brown, or other sugars used as sweeteners.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: 1 cup light brown sugar, packed
	- Context 1: Things You'll Need 1 cup light brown sugar, packed
	- Content 2: 1/2 cup brown sugar, packed
	- Context 2: In a small bowl, combine the rolled oats, 1/2 cup of flour, 1/2 cup of brown sugar, roasted pumpkin seeds, and softened butter.
```
[S3] Fat
Definition: Butter, oil, or other fats used in the batter or for greasing.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: 1/2 cup canola oil
	- Context 1: Things You'll Need 1/2 cup canola oil
	- Content 2: 1/4 cup butter, softened
	- Context 2: In a small bowl, combine the rolled oats, 1/2 cup of flour, 1/2 cup of brown sugar, roasted pumpkin seeds, and softened butter.
```
[S4] Seeds/Nuts
Definition: Seeds or nuts used as mix-ins or toppings (e.g., 'pumpkin seeds').
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: 1/2 cup roasted pumpkin seeds
	- Context 1: In a small bowl, combine the rolled oats, 1/2 cup of flour, 1/2 cup of brown sugar, roasted pumpkin seeds, and softened butter.
	- Content 2: Roasted pumpkin seeds
	- Context 2: In a small bowl, combine the rolled oats, 1/2 cup of flour, 1/2 cup of brown sugar, roasted pumpkin seeds, and softened butter. Combine thoroughly and set aside.
```
[S5] Liquid
Definition: Water, milk, buttermilk, eggs, or other liquid ingredients.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: 2 eggs, lightly beaten
	- Context 1: Things You'll Need 2 eggs, lightly beaten
	- Content 2: 1 cup buttermilk
	- Context 2: Things You'll Need 1 cup buttermilk
```
[S6] Leavening
Definition: Baking powder, baking soda, yeast or similar rising agents.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: 1 tablespoon baking powder
	- Context 1: Things You'll Need 1 tablespoon baking powder
	- Content 2: 2 tsp. baking soda
	- Context 2: Sift together 2 2/3 cups of flour, 3 tablespoons of espresso powder, 2 teaspoons of baking soda, and 1 teaspoon of salt.
```
[S7] Dairy
Definition: Milk, yogurt, cream, or cheese distinct from fats (when listed separately).
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: 8 ounces (200g) cream cheese
	- Context 1: FILLING:  8 ounces (200g) cream cheese, at room temperature  Mix together cream cheese, sugar, egg yolk and vanilla until well combined.
	- Content 2: 1 cup white chocolate chips
	- Context 2: Add 1 cup of white chocolate chips and stir until thoroughly combined.
```
[S8] Spice/Flavor
Definition: Spices and flavorings like cinnamon, vanilla, or cocoa (includes salt and small flavoring agents).
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: 1/2 teaspoon sea salt
	- Context 1: Things You'll Need 1/2 teaspoon sea salt
	- Content 2: 3 Tbsp. espresso powder
	- Context 2: Sift together 2 2/3 cups of flour, 3 tablespoons of espresso powder, 2 teaspoons of baking soda, and 1 teaspoon of salt.
```
[S9] Fruit
Definition: Fresh, canned or dried fruits intended as mix-ins or main flavor (e.g., 'pumpkin' or 'blueberries').
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: 1 2/3 cups fresh or frozen blueberries
	- Context 1: Things You'll Need 1 2/3 cups fresh or frozen blueberries
	- Content 2: 1 can of pumpkin pie filling, 15 oz.
	- Context 2: Combine the pumpkin pie filling, 1/4 cup of sugar, 1 cup of brown sugar, and 1 cup of vegetable oil.
```
[S10] Oats/Grain
Definition: Whole grains or rolled oats used as mix-ins or toppings (e.g., 'rolled oats').
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: 1/2 cup rolled oats (not instant)
	- Context 1: In a small bowl, combine the rolled oats, 1/2 cup of flour, 1/2 cup of brown sugar, roasted pumpkin seeds, and softened butter.
```
[S11] Chocolate
Definition: Chocolate chips or other confectionery chip mix-ins (e.g., 'white chocolate chips').
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: 1 cup white chocolate chips
	- Context 1: Add 1 cup of white chocolate chips and stir until thoroughly combined.
```
- Tutorial-style transcript with timestamps (in seconds):
[0 - 1] Going to the grocery store has turned into an epic quest to find the perfect bananas. In the Clothier home, we like them to still be a bit green - they are firmer and have a better flavor. But there's a lot to consider: How many to get? How many do I think we will eat in the next few days? Is one a day good, or will my wife and I both eat one each day? What about if I want to put them in cereal or something else? And the most important variable that determines if I leave with a bunch or empty handed is how green they are. Occasionally, I will find some that will be perfect in a couple of days and pair them with a few that are perfect right now.
[2 - 3] But no matter how hard I plan, there always seems to be one or two that go uneaten or ripen a lot quicker than expected. It is in these situations that I think banana bread was first conceived - a way to use those blackening bananas before they go to waste.
[4 - 5] The best thing about these muffins is the crumbly coating that goes on top of them. The added texture and flavor is well worth the extra calories.
[6 - 7] Since this is one of those things I don't make very often, I don't give much thought as to how bad it is for you. I'd rather be happy and plump than starve myself endlessly. If worse comes to worst, there's always the gym...
[8 - 9] Step 1: Ingredients
[9 - 10] For the Bread:
[10 - 11] 3 - 4 Bananas, Mashed
[11 - 12] 2 Cups all-purpose Flour
[12 - 13] 3/4 Cup White Sugar
[13 - 14] 1/4 Cup Brown Sugar
[14 - 15] 1 Stick Butter, Softened
[15 - 16] 2 Eggs, Slightly Beaten
[16 - 17] 1 tsp Vanilla
[17 - 18] 1 tsp Baking Soda
[18 - 19] 1/2 tsp Salt
[20 - 21] For the Topping:
[21 - 22] 2 Tbsp Olive Oil
[22 - 23] 1/3 Cup Brown Sugar
[23 - 24] 1 Tbsp Cinnamon
[25 - 26] Optional:
[26 - 27] 1 Cup Walnuts, Chopped
[28 - 29] Oven Temp:
[29 - 30] Once you have everything, preheat the oven to 375 degrees F.
[31 - 32] Step 2: Mush Those Bananas
[32 - 33] Peel the bananas and place them in a large bowl. It's OK if they have a few spots, but you can cut away the super gross black parts if there are any if that freaks you out. Also, peel off any of those clingy strings...
[34 - 35] Using a strong utensil, smush, smash, mush, and mash those bananas into oblivion! Be careful though, I actually shattered a spoon once when I got a bit too excited. This can be a stress reliever or an arm workout - your choice.
[36 - 37] Keep it up until the banana are mostly liquified. It's OK to have a few bits and pieces for consistency and texture.
[38 - 39] Step 3: A Sweet Start
[39 - 40] Once the butter is softened (try not to melt it completely!) combine it with 3/4 cup white sugar and 1/4 cup brown sugar. A fork or a strong whisk works best for this procedure. Mix until everything is well blended and creamy.
[41 - 42] Step 4: Mix It Up
[42 - 43] Beat the 2 eggs, vanilla and butter/sugar mixture into the bananas. If you are adding walnuts, now is a good time to do so.
[44 - 45] Step 5: Flour Is Your Friend
[45 - 46] Finally, add the flour, baking soda, and salt, and mix until it is totally incorporated. Once you are satisfied, pour the mixture into your cooking pan of choice. With this batch, I made muffins, but a loaf or cake pan is also acceptable.
[47 - 48] Step 6: Coat It...
[48 - 49] To make the topping, blend the olive oil, brown sugar, and cinnamon until it is very crumbly. Then, sprinkle it over top of the batter. It's OK to make extra and really put it on thick. Typically, butter is used to make a streusel, but there is already a stick in the batter, and I'm trying to reduce my intake. If you would rather go that route, use a one to two tablespoons of butter instead of the oil.
[50 - 51] Step 7: And Cook It
[51 - 52] In case you forgot to do so earlier, preheat the oven to 375 degrees F. When it is ready, bake the batter appropriately for your cooking pan. For muffins, 18 to 20 minutes should be good. Be sure to test them with a clean knife or toothpick to make sure they are done. When you are satisfied, let them cool on a rack for 15 minutes, or until they can be safely touched.
[53 - 54] I think you can figure out what to do after that...    

### GOAL
Return an updated list of segment labels for temporal segmentation of the tutorial based on Ingredient types (including existing and any new ones needed to cover the given transcript), each with 1-2 concrete examples grounded in the given transcript (or reused from the existing labels).

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- Read the ingredient line and identify the head noun (e.g., 'flour', 'oats', 'butter', 'pumpkin seeds').
- Map the head noun to a single broader category (Flour, Oats/Grain, Sugar, Fat, Seeds/Nuts, Liquid, Leavening, Spice/Flavoring, Dairy, Fruit).
- Ignore modifiers that affect form or preparation (e.g., 'softened', 'packed') when assigning the category.
- If ambiguous, pick the most specific category matching the head noun (e.g., 'brown sugar' → Sugar).

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### OUTPUT
Return a list of segment labels. Each segment label should have the following fields:
- id: id of the segment label
- label: short text less than 2-3 words
- definition: elaboration of what the segment label means
- examples: 1-2 short representative content and context that would be labeled as the segment label

NOTES
- Ground everything in the provided inputs; no external knowledge or speculation.
- Do not create duplicate or overlapping segment labels.
- Keep examples short and specific; avoid paraphrasing for the 'content' field.

- Tutorial-style transcript with timestamps (in seconds):
[1 - 2] There are so many things to love about this one-bowl oatmeal protein muffin recipe: It's low in sugar, flexible with substitutions and includes three simple sources of protein (nut butter, chia seeds, and flaxseed). But best of all... these muffins are seriously delicious.
[3 - 4] {image caption}{Oatmeal protein muffins with chocolate chips and banana chips}
[5 - 6] Things You'll Need
[6 - 7] 3 very ripe bananas (or 1 cup of applesauce)
[7 - 8] 1 cup milk (dairy, coconut, or almond)
[8 - 9] 1/2 cup peanut butter (or any nut butter)
[9 - 10] 2 eggs
[10 - 11] 1/4 cup maple syrup (or honey)
[11 - 12] 1 teaspoon vanilla
[12 - 13] 1 tablespoon baking powder
[13 - 14] 1/4 cup flaxseed (ground)
[14 - 15] 1 tablespoon chia seeds
[15 - 16] 3 cups whole oats
[16 - 17] Optional toppings: chocolate chips, dried banana chips
[18 - 19] Tip
[19 - 20] The peanut butter-banana base can be adapted to suit many different tastes. Applesauce works in place of bananas and any nut butter can pinch hit for the peanut butter.
[21 - 22] {image caption}{Ingredients for oatmeal protein muffins}
[23 - 24] Get Started
[24 - 25] Set your oven to 375 degrees F and grease the muffin pan. Use coconut oil, spray or butter to grease your pan. Next, mash your bananas in a large mixing bowl.
[26 - 27] {image caption}{When it comes to baking with bananas, the browner the better. They'll have more flavor.}
[28 - 29] {image caption}{A potato masher works best but a fork would also do for very ripe bananas.}
[30 - 31] Add the Remaining Ingredients
[31 - 32] There's no way to mess this up. Simply combine all the ingredients and stir until thoroughly mixed.
[33 - 34] {image caption}{Use regular milk, almond milk or coconut milk.}
[35 - 36] {image caption}{No need to beat the eggs ahead of time, just crack and mix.}
[37 - 38] {image caption}{We used maple syrup here but honey is also delicious.}
[39 - 40] {image caption}{Make this recipe gluten-free with specially marked containers of whole oats.}
[41 - 42] {image caption}{Without flour in the recipe, there's no worry of over-mixing.}
[43 - 44] Prepare to Bake
[44 - 45] Fill muffin cups to the top. A 3-ounce ice cream scoop works perfectly for evenly distributing muffin batter into pans. This is the time to add optional toppings such as chocolate chips or banana chips.
[46 - 47] {image caption}{Tip: Place a couple of chocolate or banana chips in the bottom of each cup before ladling in the batter.}
[48 - 49] {image caption}{Try using coconut oil spray to grease the pan. It's delicious!}
[50 - 51] Bake at 375 degrees F for 25 minutes. Then cool on a rack.
[52 - 53] {image caption}{Oatmeal protein muffins with banana chips on top}
[54 - 55] Store refrigerated in an airtight container for 3 to 5 days. Or freeze in a single layer, inside a zip-top freezer bag.
[56 - 57] {image caption}{Mix and match your toppings, or add more.}    

### GOAL
Return an updated list of segment labels for temporal segmentation of the tutorial based on Ingredient types (including existing and any new ones needed to cover the given transcript), each with 1-2 concrete examples grounded in the given transcript (or reused from the existing labels).

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- Read the ingredient line and identify the head noun (e.g., 'flour', 'oats', 'butter', 'pumpkin seeds').
- Map the head noun to a single broader category (Flour, Oats/Grain, Sugar, Fat, Seeds/Nuts, Liquid, Leavening, Spice/Flavoring, Dairy, Fruit).
- Ignore modifiers that affect form or preparation (e.g., 'softened', 'packed') when assigning the category.
- If ambiguous, pick the most specific category matching the head noun (e.g., 'brown sugar' → Sugar).

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.

ROLE: user

You are discovering segment labels for temporal segmentation of a tutorial for a task Making Muffins based on Ingredient types (i.e., Group each ingredient line by the head-noun's broad ingredient category (e.g., flour → Flour; rolled oats → Oats/Grain; butter → Fat). ### INPUTS
- Existing segment labels:
[S1] Flour
Definition: Ground-wheat or baking flours used as the dry base (e.g., 'all-purpose flour').
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: 2 Cups all-purpose Flour
	- Context 1: For the Bread: 2 Cups all-purpose Flour
	- Content 2: Finally, add the flour
	- Context 2: Finally, add the flour, baking soda, and salt, and mix until it is totally incorporated.
```
[S2] Sugar
Definition: Granulated, brown, or other sugars and syrup sweeteners (e.g., maple syrup, honey).
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: 1/4 cup maple syrup
	- Context 1: 1/4 cup maple syrup (or honey)
	- Content 2: 3/4 Cup White Sugar
	- Context 2: For the Bread: 3/4 Cup White Sugar
```
[S3] Fat
Definition: Butter, oil, nut butters, or other fats used in the batter or for greasing.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: 1/2 cup peanut butter
	- Context 1: 1/2 cup peanut butter (or any nut butter)
	- Content 2: grease the muffin pan
	- Context 2: Set your oven to 375 degrees F and grease the muffin pan. Use coconut oil, spray or butter to grease your pan.
```
[S4] Seeds/Nuts
Definition: Seeds or nuts used as mix-ins or toppings (e.g., flaxseed, chia, walnuts, pumpkin seeds).
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: 1/4 cup flaxseed (ground)
	- Context 1: 1/4 cup flaxseed (ground)
	- Content 2: 1 tablespoon chia seeds
	- Context 2: 1 tablespoon chia seeds
```
[S5] Liquid
Definition: Liquid ingredients such as eggs or other non-dairy liquids used in the recipe.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: 2 eggs
	- Context 1: 2 eggs
	- Content 2: 2 Eggs, Slightly Beaten
	- Context 2: For the Bread: 2 Eggs, Slightly Beaten
```
[S6] Leavening
Definition: Baking powder, baking soda, yeast, or similar rising agents.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: 1 tablespoon baking powder
	- Context 1: 1 tablespoon baking powder
	- Content 2: 1 tsp Baking Soda
	- Context 2: For the Bread: 1 tsp Baking Soda
```
[S7] Dairy
Definition: Milk, yogurt, cream, or cheese distinct from fats (when listed separately).
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: 1 cup milk
	- Context 1: 1 cup milk (dairy, coconut, or almond)
	- Content 2: 1 cup milk (dairy, coconut, or almond)
	- Context 2: Use regular milk, almond milk or coconut milk.
```
[S8] Spice/Flavor
Definition: Spices and flavorings like vanilla, cinnamon, or small flavoring agents (includes salt).
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: 1 teaspoon vanilla
	- Context 1: 1 teaspoon vanilla
	- Content 2: 1 tsp Vanilla
	- Context 2: For the Bread: 1 tsp Vanilla
```
[S9] Fruit
Definition: Fresh, canned or dried fruits intended as mix-ins or main flavor (e.g., bananas, applesauce, dried fruit).
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: 3 very ripe bananas
	- Context 1: 3 very ripe bananas (or 1 cup of applesauce)
	- Content 2: dried banana chips
	- Context 2: Optional toppings: chocolate chips, dried banana chips
```
[S10] Oats/Grain
Definition: Whole grains or rolled oats used as mix-ins or base (e.g., 'whole oats', 'rolled oats').
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: 3 cups whole oats
	- Context 1: 3 cups whole oats
	- Content 2: 1/2 cup rolled oats (not instant)
	- Context 2: In a small bowl, combine the rolled oats, 1/2 cup of flour, 1/2 cup of brown sugar, roasted pumpkin seeds, and softened butter.
```
[S11] Chocolate
Definition: Chocolate chips or other confectionery chip mix-ins (e.g., 'white chocolate chips').
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: Optional toppings: chocolate chips
	- Context 1: Optional toppings: chocolate chips, dried banana chips
	- Content 2: chocolate chips
	- Context 2: Tip: Place a couple of chocolate or banana chips in the bottom of each cup before ladling in the batter.
```
- Tutorial-style transcript with timestamps (in seconds):
[0 - 1] Homemade muffins are a special addition to breakfast or brunch. Enjoy them with friends and family, or make them as a grab-and-go breakfast for busy work weeks. Warmly spiced with cinnamon, Morning Glory muffins are made with grated carrot, apple, raisins, walnuts, shredded coconut, and sometimes pineapple. While the list of ingredients is long, the process for baking these muffins is simple and well worth the required steps.
[2 - 3] ​​This recipe makes 12 muffins. ​
[4 - 5] Things You'll Need
[5 - 6] 1-1/4 cups all-purpose flour
[6 - 7] 1 cup shredded coconut
[7 - 8] 3/4 cup light brown sugar, tightly packed
[8 - 9] 1-1/2 teaspoons ground cinnamon
[9 - 10] 1/2 teaspoon sea salt
[10 - 11] 1 teaspoon baking powder
[11 - 12] 1 cup grated carrot (about 1 large carrot, peeled and grated)
[12 - 13] 1 cup grated apple (about 1/2 large apple such as Honeycrisp)
[13 - 14] 1/2 cup raisins
[14 - 15] 1/2 cup raw walnuts, chopped
[15 - 16] 2 large eggs
[16 - 17] 1/4 cup olive oil or canola oil
[17 - 18] 2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract
[18 - 19] Box grater
[19 - 20] 2 mixing bowls
[20 - 21] Spoon or fork for mixing
[21 - 22] 12 disposable baking cups
[22 - 23] 12-hole muffin tray
[23 - 24] Tip
[24 - 25] To save time, use a food processor to shred the carrot and apple.
[25 - 26] Not a fan of gluten? Replace the all-purpose flour with gluten-free all-purpose flour.
[26 - 27] For naturally sweetened, refined sugar-free muffins, replace the brown sugar with coconut sugar.
[27 - 28] You can choose to use sweetened or unsweetened shredded coconut.
[28 - 29] Instructions:
[29 - 30] Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F. Grate 1 cup-worth of carrot, and 1 cup-worth of apple.
[31 - 32] Add the flour, cinnamon, brown sugar, baking powder, and salt to a mixing and stir together.
[33 - 34] Add the grated carrot, apple, raisins, and walnuts to the flour mixture and stir to combine.
[35 - 36] In a separate bowl, whisk together the eggs, oil, and vanilla extract.
[37 - 38] Add the egg mixture to the bowl with the flour mixture and stir well until a thick batter forms.
[39 - 40] Line a 12-hole muffin pan with baking cups. Scoop batter into the pan using an ice cream scoop or small measuring cup, filling the holes 2/3 of the way up.
[41 - 42] Bake on the center rack of the preheated oven for 30 to 40 minutes, or until muffins test clean when poked with a toothpick.
[43 - 44] Allow muffins to cool for 10 minutes before serving. Enjoy!    

### GOAL
Return an updated list of segment labels for temporal segmentation of the tutorial based on Ingredient types (including existing and any new ones needed to cover the given transcript), each with 1-2 concrete examples grounded in the given transcript (or reused from the existing labels).

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- Read the ingredient line and identify the head noun (e.g., 'flour', 'oats', 'butter', 'pumpkin seeds').
- Map the head noun to a single broader category (Flour, Oats/Grain, Sugar, Fat, Seeds/Nuts, Liquid, Leavening, Spice/Flavoring, Dairy, Fruit).
- Ignore modifiers that affect form or preparation (e.g., 'softened', 'packed') when assigning the category.
- If ambiguous, pick the most specific category matching the head noun (e.g., 'brown sugar' → Sugar).

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### OUTPUT
Return a list of segment labels. Each segment label should have the following fields:
- id: id of the segment label
- label: short text less than 2-3 words
- definition: elaboration of what the segment label means
- examples: 1-2 short representative content and context that would be labeled as the segment label

NOTES
- Ground everything in the provided inputs; no external knowledge or speculation.
- Do not create duplicate or overlapping segment labels.
- Keep examples short and specific; avoid paraphrasing for the 'content' field.

[0 - 1] These are my blueberry muffins.
[4 - 5] Mmm, my favorite muffin.
[5 - 12] To a large mixing bowl, add grated lemon zest, a milk of choice, we're using soy milk, sugar, a neutral vegetable oil, and vanilla extract.
[12 - 14] Whisk well until the ingredients are well combined.
[14 - 18] Now, sift in the flour with baking powder and a pinch of salt.
[18 - 20] This is gonna make your muffin soft and fluffy.
[20 - 24] Whisk wet and dry ingredients for a short minute until lumps are gone, but without overmixing.
[24 - 29] Rinse the blueberries, shake the water off, then add them to a bowl, toss them with the cornstarch, and add them to the batter.
[29 - 31] Stir and fold the blueberries in the mixture gently.
[31 - 33] Transfer the batter to the muffin liners.
[33 - 35] You should be able to make 12 muffins.
[35 - 37] You can fill them almost to the top.
[37 - 39] Then you can sprinkle some sugar on top, or not.
[39 - 40] We're not gonna do it because we eat them for breakfast.
[41 - 46] Then bake in a preheated oven for 22 and a half minutes, or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out dry.
[46 - 48] Now let them cool down for about 30 minutes.
[48 - 49] Easy, right?    

### GOAL
Return an updated list of segment labels for temporal segmentation of the tutorial based on Ingredient types (including existing and any new ones needed to cover the given transcript), each with 1-2 concrete examples grounded in the given transcript (or reused from the existing labels).

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- Read the ingredient line and identify the head noun (e.g., 'flour', 'oats', 'butter', 'pumpkin seeds').
- Map the head noun to a single broader category (Flour, Oats/Grain, Sugar, Fat, Seeds/Nuts, Liquid, Leavening, Spice/Flavoring, Dairy, Fruit).
- Ignore modifiers that affect form or preparation (e.g., 'softened', 'packed') when assigning the category.
- If ambiguous, pick the most specific category matching the head noun (e.g., 'brown sugar' → Sugar).

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### OUTPUT
Return a list of segment labels. Each segment label should have the following fields:
- id: id of the segment label
- label: short text less than 2-3 words
- definition: elaboration of what the segment label means
- examples: 1-2 short representative content and context that would be labeled as the segment label

NOTES
- Ground everything in the provided inputs; no external knowledge or speculation.
- Do not create duplicate or overlapping segment labels.
- Keep examples short and specific; avoid paraphrasing for the 'content' field.

- Existing segment labels:
[S1] Flour
Definition: Ground-wheat or baking flours used as the dry base (e.g., 'all-purpose flour').
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: sift in the flour
	- Context 1: Now, sift in the flour with baking powder and a pinch of salt.
	- Content 2: 1-1/4 cups all-purpose flour
	- Context 2: Things You'll Need 1-1/4 cups all-purpose flour
```
[S2] Sugar
Definition: Granulated, brown, or other sugars and syrup sweeteners (e.g., maple syrup, honey).
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: sugar
	- Context 1: To a large mixing bowl, add grated lemon zest, a milk of choice, we're using soy milk, sugar, a neutral vegetable oil, and vanilla extract.
	- Content 2: sprinkle some sugar
	- Context 2: Then you can sprinkle some sugar on top, or not.
```
[S3] Fat
Definition: Butter, oil, nut butters, or other fats used in the batter or for greasing.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: a neutral vegetable oil
	- Context 1: To a large mixing bowl, add grated lemon zest, a milk of choice, we're using soy milk, sugar, a neutral vegetable oil, and vanilla extract.
	- Content 2: 1/4 cup olive oil or canola oil
	- Context 2: Things You'll Need 1/4 cup olive oil or canola oil
```
[S4] Seeds/Nuts
Definition: Seeds or nuts used as mix-ins or toppings (e.g., flaxseed, chia, walnuts, pumpkin seeds).
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: 1/2 cup raw walnuts, chopped
	- Context 1: Things You'll Need 1/2 cup raw walnuts, chopped
	- Content 2: 1/4 cup flaxseed (ground)
	- Context 2: 1/4 cup flaxseed (ground)
```
[S5] Liquid
Definition: Liquid ingredients such as eggs or other non-dairy liquids used in the recipe.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: a milk of choice
	- Context 1: To a large mixing bowl, add grated lemon zest, a milk of choice, we're using soy milk, sugar, a neutral vegetable oil, and vanilla extract.
	- Content 2: 2 large eggs
	- Context 2: Things You'll Need 2 large eggs
```
[S6] Leavening
Definition: Baking powder, baking soda, yeast, or similar rising agents.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: baking powder
	- Context 1: Now, sift in the flour with baking powder and a pinch of salt.
	- Content 2: 1 teaspoon baking powder
	- Context 2: Things You'll Need 1 teaspoon baking powder
```
[S7] Dairy
Definition: Milk, yogurt, cream, or cheese distinct from fats (when listed separately).
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: we're using soy milk
	- Context 1: To a large mixing bowl, add grated lemon zest, a milk of choice, we're using soy milk, sugar, a neutral vegetable oil, and vanilla extract.
	- Content 2: 1 cup milk
	- Context 2: 1 cup milk (dairy, coconut, or almond)
```
[S8] Spice/Flavor
Definition: Spices and flavorings like vanilla, cinnamon, or small flavoring agents (includes salt).
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: grated lemon zest
	- Context 1: To a large mixing bowl, add grated lemon zest, a milk of choice, we're using soy milk, sugar, a neutral vegetable oil, and vanilla extract.
	- Content 2: vanilla extract
	- Context 2: To a large mixing bowl, add grated lemon zest, a milk of choice, we're using soy milk, sugar, a neutral vegetable oil, and vanilla extract.
```
[S9] Fruit
Definition: Fresh, canned or dried fruits intended as mix-ins or main flavor (e.g., bananas, applesauce, dried fruit).
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: Blueberries
	- Context 1: Rinse the blueberries, shake the water off, then add them to a bowl, toss them with the cornstarch, and add them to the batter.
	- Content 2: 1/2 cup raisins
	- Context 2: Things You'll Need 1/2 cup raisins
```
[S10] Oats/Grain

	- Content 1: 3 cups whole oats
	- Context 1: 3 cups whole oats
	- Content 2: 1/2 cup rolled oats
	- Context 2: In a small bowl, combine the rolled oats, 1/2 cup of flour, 1/2 cup of brown sugar, roasted pumpkin seeds, and softened butter.
```
[S11] Chocolate
Definition: Chocolate chips or other confectionery chip mix-ins (e.g., 'white chocolate chips').
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: chocolate chips
	- Context 1: Optional toppings: chocolate chips, dried banana chips
	- Content 2: chocolate chips
	- Context 2: Tip: Place a couple of chocolate or banana chips in the bottom of each cup before ladling in the batter.
```
[S12] Vegetable
Definition: Vegetable ingredients used as mix-ins or flavor (e.g., grated carrot).
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: 1 cup grated carrot
	- Context 1: Things You'll Need 1 cup grated carrot (about 1 large carrot, peeled and grated)
	- Content 2: Grate 1 cup-worth of carrot
	- Context 2: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F. Grate 1 cup-worth of carrot, and 1 cup-worth of apple.
```
[S13] Starch
Definition: Starch or thickening agents used to coat fruit or thicken batters (e.g., cornstarch).
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: the cornstarch
	- Context 1: Rinse the blueberries, shake the water off, then add them to a bowl, toss them with the cornstarch, and add them to the batter.
```

[0 - 4] Now that I've successfully learnt how to make muffins, I had to make a triple chocolate version.
[4 - 7] Add all the wet ingredients to a bowl and whisk until combined.
[7 - 10] In another bowl, add the flour, cocoa powder and caster sugar and whisk these together.
[10 - 12] Then add your chocolate chips.
[12 - 14] Coating them in the flour helps stop them from sinking.
[14 - 17] Fold the wet ingredients into the mix, then refrigerate for at least one hour.
[17 - 19] This helps them rise without overflowing.
[19 - 23] Scoop the batter into muffin cases, then top with a mix of chocolate chips.
[23 - 25] Follow these baking instructions and that's it.
[25 - 25] Enjoy!

	- Content 1: caster sugar
	- Context 1: In another bowl, add the flour, cocoa powder and caster sugar and whisk these together.
	- Content 2: sugar
	- Context 2: To a large mixing bowl, add grated lemon zest, a milk of choice, we're using soy milk, sugar, a neutral vegetable oil, and vanilla extract.
```
[S3] Fat
Definition: Butter, oil, nut butters, or other fats used in the batter or for greasing.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: a neutral vegetable oil
	- Context 1: To a large mixing bowl, add grated lemon zest, a milk of choice, we're using soy milk, sugar, a neutral vegetable oil, and vanilla extract.
	- Content 2: 1/4 cup olive oil or canola oil
	- Context 2: Things You'll Need 1/4 cup olive oil or canola oil
```
[S4] Seeds/Nuts
Definition: Seeds or nuts used as mix-ins or toppings (e.g., flaxseed, chia, walnuts, pumpkin seeds).
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: 1/2 cup raw walnuts, chopped
	- Context 1: Things You'll Need 1/2 cup raw walnuts, chopped
	- Content 2: 1/4 cup flaxseed (ground)
	- Context 2: 1/4 cup flaxseed (ground)
```
[S5] Liquid
Definition: Liquid ingredients such as eggs or other non-dairy liquids used in the recipe.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: a milk of choice
	- Context 1: To a large mixing bowl, add grated lemon zest, a milk of choice, we're using soy milk, sugar, a neutral vegetable oil, and vanilla extract.
	- Content 2: 2 large eggs
	- Context 2: Things You'll Need 2 large eggs
```
[S6] Leavening
Definition: Baking powder, baking soda, yeast, or similar rising agents.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: baking powder
	- Context 1: Now, sift in the flour with baking powder and a pinch of salt.
	- Content 2: 1 teaspoon baking powder
	- Context 2: Things You'll Need 1 teaspoon baking powder
```
[S7] Dairy
Definition: Milk, yogurt, cream, or cheese distinct from fats (when listed separately).
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: we're using soy milk
	- Context 1: To a large mixing bowl, add grated lemon zest, a milk of choice, we're using soy milk, sugar, a neutral vegetable oil, and vanilla extract.
	- Content 2: 1 cup milk
	- Context 2: 1 cup milk (dairy, coconut, or almond)
```
[S8] Spice/Flavor
Definition: Spices and flavorings like vanilla, cinnamon, or small flavoring agents (includes salt and powdered flavorings such as cocoa).
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: cocoa powder
	- Context 1: In another bowl, add the flour, cocoa powder and caster sugar and whisk these together.
	- Content 2: vanilla extract
	- Context 2: To a large mixing bowl, add grated lemon zest, a milk of choice, we're using soy milk, sugar, a neutral vegetable oil, and vanilla extract.
```
[S9] Fruit
Definition: Fresh, canned or dried fruits intended as mix-ins or main flavor (e.g., bananas, applesauce, dried fruit).
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: Blueberries
	- Context 1: Rinse the blueberries, shake the water off, then add them to a bowl, toss them with the cornstarch, and add them to the batter.
	- Content 2: 1/2 cup raisins
	- Context 2: Things You'll Need 1/2 cup raisins
```
[S10] Oats/Grain
Definition: Whole grains or rolled oats used as mix-ins or base (e.g., 'whole oats', 'rolled oats').
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: 1/2 cup rolled oats
	- Context 1: In a small bowl, combine the rolled oats, 1/2 cup of flour, 1/2 cup of brown sugar, roasted pumpkin seeds, and softened butter.
	- Content 2: 3 cups whole oats
	- Context 2: 3 cups whole oats
```
[S11] Chocolate
Definition: Chocolate chips or other confectionery chip mix-ins (e.g., 'white chocolate chips').
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: chocolate chips
	- Context 1: Then add your chocolate chips.
	- Content 2: chocolate chips
	- Context 2: Scoop the batter into muffin cases, then top with a mix of chocolate chips.
```
[S12] Vegetable
Definition: Vegetable ingredients used as mix-ins or flavor (e.g., grated carrot).
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: 1 cup grated carrot
	- Context 1: Things You'll Need 1 cup grated carrot (about 1 large carrot, peeled and grated)
	- Content 2: Grate 1 cup-worth of carrot
	- Context 2: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F. Grate 1 cup-worth of carrot, and 1 cup-worth of apple.
```
[S13] Starch
Definition: Starch or thickening agents used to coat fruit or thicken batters (e.g., cornstarch).
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: the cornstarch
	- Context 1: Rinse the blueberries, shake the water off, then add them to a bowl, toss them with the cornstarch, and add them to the batter.
```

[0 - 6] Do you love moist, fluffy chocolate chip muffins with that skyhigh bakery top and a nice crisp edge?
[6 - 9] Well, today's your lucky day because I'm gonna show you how to make them.
[9 - 14] Hey, you're watching Preppy Kitchen, where I, John Kanell, teach you how to make delicious homemade dishes to share with your family and friends.
[14 - 17] These chocolate chip muffins are gonna whip up in a snap, so let's get started.

[21 - 31] We want a really high blast of heat when these go in because that'll set the edge and let them rise up so you'll have a nice bakerystyle dome on top.
[31 - 36] If you did 350, they would spread out and it just wouldn't be the right kind of muffin.
[36 - 38] Okay, now for the dry ingredients.

[217 - 220] So you can see we have a couple clumps here and there, but it's no big deal.

[224 - 233] All right, in my recipe, I specify 1 12 cups of semisweet chocolate, but I'm living large and using one cup of semisweet and half a cup of bittersweet.
[234 - 237] You could even use milk chocolate if that's what you prefer.

[238 - 248] That's the bittersweet chocolate, and I'm taking a handful of the semisweet chips and reserving them, because I'll be sprinkling them on top for beauty purposes.
[248 - 254] Rest of the chocolate chips go in, and you should fold them in with a spatula, not use a whisk.
[254 - 258] After those chocolate chips are folded in, it's time to pop this into the muffin tins.
[259 - 264] I'm doing it two different ways so you can see the difference between a naked muffin and one that's in the paper.

[277 - 287] All right, and for the rest, I'm gonna use muffin papers, which go a bit higher, so you won't have that mushroomshaped muffin top, but they should still rise up with a nice dome.

[335 - 341] After the batter goes in, you can top the muffins with a scattering of chocolate chips.

[349 - 353] The chocolate chip muffins look a little bit naked if they don't have those chocolate chips on top.

[359 - 368] You need to have a high heat to lock in the edge so it gets set, and then the top can burst through to create that big bakerystyle dome.
[368 - 386] This is gonna go into the oven at 425 Fahrenheit for five minutes, then it'll reduce the temperature to 350 and bake for 20 to 25 minutes, depending, you wanna have a nice golden top that's set in the middle, so you can insert a skewer through the center, it'll come out clean except for all that molten chocolate.

### GOAL
Return an updated list of segment labels for temporal segmentation of the tutorial based on Ingredient types (including existing and any new ones needed to cover the given transcript), each with 1-2 concrete examples grounded in the given transcript (or reused from the existing labels).

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- Read the ingredient line and identify the head noun (e.g., 'flour', 'oats', 'butter', 'pumpkin seeds').
- Map the head noun to a single broader category (Flour, Oats/Grain, Sugar, Fat, Seeds/Nuts, Liquid, Leavening, Spice/Flavoring, Dairy, Fruit).
- Ignore modifiers that affect form or preparation (e.g., 'softened', 'packed') when assigning the category.
- If ambiguous, pick the most specific category matching the head noun (e.g., 'brown sugar' → Sugar).

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### OUTPUT
Return a list of segment labels. Each segment label should have the following fields:
- id: id of the segment label
- label: short text less than 2-3 words
- definition: elaboration of what the segment label means
- examples: 1-2 short representative content and context that would be labeled as the segment label

NOTES
- Ground everything in the provided inputs; no external knowledge or speculation.
- Do not create duplicate or overlapping segment labels.
- Keep examples short and specific; avoid paraphrasing for the 'content' field.
